But eventually, the spell begins to fray around the edges. Dreams start to leak through, fragments of the truth trying to surface. Tell me honestly, Dmitri—haven't you been having dreams lately? The dreams had been growing more vivid and frequent over the past months, filled with images that made no sense but felt more real than his waking life. A woman's laughter echoing across dark water. The sensation of rain on his skin that felt like a caress rather than a threat. His own voice, younger and unafraid, speaking words of power that made the very air shimmer with possibility. "Dreams don't mean anything," he said, but his voice lacked conviction. "They're just the mind's way of processing fears and anxieties. Any decent practitioner knows that magic and psychology often get tangled together." He was quoting from one of the texts he'd cataloged at the library, though he couldn't remember which one. The familiar academic language felt like armor against the chaos Katarina was trying to introduce into his carefully ordered world.

"Is that what you tell yourself when you wake up crying?" Katarina asked, and the gentleness in her voice was somehow worse than her earlier mockery had been. "When you find yourself reaching for someone who isn't there, calling out a name you can't quite remember? Oh, Dima, what did they do to you? The endearment—Dima, the nickname only his grandmother had ever used—hit him like a physical blow. For a moment the café seemed to fade around them, replaced by the image of a sun-drenched meadow beside a crystal-clear lake. A younger Katarina was there, her red hair loose and wild, teaching him to skip stones across the water while she told jokes that made him blush and laugh in equal measure. Her hand was warm in his as she showed him how to feel the rhythm of the water, how to work with its natural flow rather than fighting against it.

His grandmother had tried to teach him, yes, but every lesson had ended in panic attacks and trembling fits that lasted for hours. The very idea of working magic on a lake was so far beyond his capabilities that it was laughable.

"Stop it," he said, pulling his hand away from hers with more force than was strictly necessary. "I don't know what kind of spell you're trying to work on me, but it won't succeed. Memory manipulation is illegal among our kind, and if you think you can confuse me with false images—"

"False?" Katarina's eyes flashed with sudden anger, and the temperature in the café dropped several degrees. Ice began to form on the inside of the windows, delicate patterns that spelled out words in the old tongue—words of love and loss and betrayal that made Dmitri's chest tighten with emotions he couldn't name. "You think what we had was false? You think the three years we spent together, the magic we created, the promises we made—you think all of that was some elaborate deception?"

The other café patrons were beginning to notice the sudden chill and the strange frost patterns on the windows. A few were gathering their coats and heading for the door, muttering about faulty heating and unseasonable weather. The waitress behind the counter kept glancing nervously in their direction, though she couldn't seem to pinpoint the source of her unease.

"Three years," Dmitri repeated, testing the words. "You're claiming we were together for three years, and I simply forgot? That's not how memory works, magical or otherwise. But even as he spoke, he was remembering the sessions with the mind-healers after his grandmother's death, the long months of therapeutic work that had helped him cope with his trauma. Had there been gaps in those memories? Periods of time that seemed strangely empty, explanations for his fears that didn't quite add up?

"Can't you?" Katarina asked, and now her voice carried a note of something that might have been desperation. "What if the person volunteering for the memory modification was in such pain that they begged for it? What if they were so terrified, so completely broken by what had happened, that they would rather lose everything—every moment of joy, every whisper of love, every shared laugh and secret and promise—rather than live with the memory of how it all ended?"

The ice on the windows was spreading now, creating elaborate murals that seemed to tell a story. Two figures walking hand in hand through a forest glade. The same figures standing together on a hilltop, arms raised to call down lightning from a storm-heavy sky. A third scene showing them in what looked like mortal combat, power crackling between them while water and fire clashed in a display that should have been impossible for Dmitri to witness, let alone participate in.

**Chapter 2**

The ice murals on the café windows continued their silent storytelling, each crystalline scene more elaborate than the last. Dmitri found himself transfixed by the images despite his rational mind's protests that this was all some form of elaborate magical deception. The figures in the frost looked undeniably like him and Katarina, but they moved with a confidence and intimacy that felt foreign to everything he understood about himself. In one panel, the Dmitri-figure stood waist-deep in a lake, arms outstretched as pillars of flame danced across the water's surface in impossible spirals. In another, both figures worked together to weave what appeared to be a massive storm, their combined magic creating patterns in the clouds that resembled ancient runic scripts.

"This is impossible," Dmitri whispered, but his voice lacked the conviction he was trying to project. The academic part of his mind was cataloging the magical techniques displayed in the frost art, recognizing advanced forms of elemental manipulation that should have taken decades to master. More disturbing still, he could almost feel the echo of those spells in his own magical core, as if his body remembered casting them even though his mind insisted otherwise. His hands were trembling now, not from cold but from something deeper—a resonance that seemed to vibrate in his very bones.

Katarina followed his gaze to the windows, her expression softening as she watched the frozen scenes play out their silent drama. "Do you remember the night we created the Aurora Moscovensis? The memory hit him like a physical blow, sudden and complete and devastating in its clarity. He could feel the wind whipping around the tower's ancient stones, could smell the metallic scent of snow in the air, could hear Katarina's voice raised in harmony with his own as they sang the old words that pulled celestial fire down from the heavens. Most vivid of all was the sensation of their magic intertwining, fire and water working in perfect synchronization to create something neither could have achieved alone. The lights had been green and gold and silver, streaming across the sky in patterns that made even the most hardened Muscovites weep with wonder, and afterwards they had held each other on the narrow tower walkway, exhausted and exhilarated and more deeply connected than he had ever felt with another human being.

"No," he said, pressing his palms against his temples as if he could physically force the memory back into whatever dark corner it had emerged from. "No, that never happened. I would remember something like that. You can't just forget working magic on that scale, the kind of power drain alone would leave permanent traces in a practitioner's core signature." But even as he spoke, he was aware of the odd gaps in his magical training, techniques he seemed to know instinctively despite never learning them, a capacity for channeling energy that far exceeded what his documented practice should have developed.

The other café patrons had all fled now, leaving them alone with the increasingly elaborate ice murals and the nervous waitress who kept making excuses to retreat further behind her counter. Katarina reached across the table again, but this time Dmitri didn't pull away when she took his hands in hers. Her touch was warm despite the magical cold she had been generating, and he could feel her water magic flowing under her skin like a living thing, complex and powerful and strangely familiar.

"The mind-healers you saw after Baba Yelena's death," Katarina said gently, her thumbs tracing small circles on his knuckles, "did they ever explain exactly what kind of trauma therapy they were providing? Did they tell you why a simple case of hydrophobia required such extensive magical intervention, why you needed to spend six months in their care instead of a few weeks with a conventional therapist?" Her voice was patient now, the tone of someone guiding a patient through a difficult revelation. "Think, Dima. What did they tell you about the gaps in your memory from that summer? How did they explain why you couldn't remember the three months leading up to your grandmother's accident?"

Dmitri tried to focus on those sessions, but the memories seemed strangely blurred around the edges, lacking the sharp detail he would have expected from such a significant period of his life. He remembered the clean white rooms of the healing center, the gentle voices of the therapists, the gradual lessening of his panic attacks around water. But the specific conversations, the explanations for his condition, the details of his treatment—all of that seemed wrapped in a soft gray fog that his mind couldn't quite penetrate.

"They said the trauma had caused some temporary amnesia," he said slowly, frowning as he tried to bring the memories into clearer focus. "That it was normal for victims of magical accidents to lose some time around the incident. They said the memories might return eventually, but that it would be healthier if I didn't try to force the process." Even as he spoke the words, they sounded hollow and insufficient, the sort of vague explanations that were designed to discourage further questions rather than provide real understanding.

Katarina's grip on his hands tightened, and when she spoke, her voice was thick with an emotion he couldn't identify. "There was no accident, Dima. Baba Yelena didn't die because of some random magical mishap or a failed attempt to cure your phobia. She died because she tried to stop what was happening between us, because she was terrified of the kind of power we were generating together, and because when she finally acted against us, I..." Her voice broke, and she looked away toward the frost-covered windows where new scenes were forming—darker images now, showing conflict and violence and a terrible magical storm that seemed to tear the very air apart.

"Because you what?" Dmitri asked, though part of him desperately didn't want to hear the answer. The trembling in his hands was getting worse, and he could feel his own fire magic beginning to respond to his emotional state, small flames dancing between his fingers without conscious direction. The combination of his fire and her water magic should have created dangerous instabilities in the local magical field, but instead the energies seemed to be harmonizing, creating a resonance that made the air itself shimmer with power.

Katarina turned back to him, and the pain in her eyes was so raw and immediate that it felt like looking directly into an open wound. "Because I killed her, Dima. Not intentionally, not maliciously, but I killed her all the same. She came to confront us while we were working the Tempest of Sorrows—do you remember that spell? The one that was supposed to cleanse Moscow of three generations of accumulated grief and trauma? She tried to break our circle while we were in the deepest part of the working, and the backlash..." She closed her eyes, and when she opened them again, tears were streaming down her cheeks. "The backlash tore her apart. Literally. There wasn't enough left of her to properly bury."

The final memory came back in a rush so powerful that Dmitri actually cried out, his entire body convulsing as if he'd been struck by lightning. He could see it all now with horrible clarity—the ritual circle on the shore of the lake, the massive storm they had called up to serve as a focus for their magic, Katarina beside him with her arms raised and her hair whipping in the supernatural wind, their voices joined in the complex harmonies that were meant to transmute centuries of human suffering into healing energy. And then Baba Yelena appearing at the edge of the circle, her face twisted with fear and fury, shouting warnings about forbidden magic and dangerous resonances and the terrible price of trying to heal trauma on such a massive scale.

He remembered his grandmother stepping into the circle despite their frantic warnings, remembered the way the magical energies had immediately begun to destabilize as she tried to force a premature ending to their working. Most vividly of all, he remembered the moment when the storm's power had found a new outlet in her unprotected body, the way she had simply come apart like a flower in a hurricane, her final scream lost in the thunder they had called down from the heavens.

"Oh god," he whispered, and then louder, "Oh god, oh god, we killed her. We killed her and I let them make me forget, I let them take away everything because I couldn't live with what we'd done." The flames around his hands were growing larger now, responding to his anguish, and he could feel his magical control beginning to slip in ways that hadn't happened since he was a child. The memory of his grandmother's death was bad enough, but worse was the knowledge that he had chosen to forget, had voluntarily surrendered three years of love and partnership and magical discovery because the guilt had been too overwhelming to bear.

Katarina was around the table now, kneeling beside his chair and pulling him against her chest as he shook with sobs he couldn't control. Her water magic was flowing around them both, not trying to suppress his fire but instead containing it, channeling it into harmless patterns that dissipated into the air without damaging anything. It was a level of magical cooperation that should have required years of practice to achieve, but it felt as natural as breathing, as if their energies had been designed to work in perfect harmony.

"I'm sorry," she whispered into his hair, her own tears falling hot against his scalp. "I'm so sorry, love. I should have stopped the working when she appeared, should have found a way to break the circle safely. But I was so sure we could complete it, so convinced that what we were doing was right and necessary and beautiful. I thought she would understand once she saw what we were trying to accomplish, thought she would see that we weren't just playing with dangerous magic but actually trying to heal something broken in the world."

Dmitri pulled back far enough to look at her face, seeing his own grief and guilt reflected in her green eyes. "Why didn't you have the memories removed too? Why did you choose to remember when I chose to forget?" The question came out harsher than he had intended, carrying an undertone of accusation that he immediately regretted. But he needed to understand how she had lived with this knowledge for so long, how she had carried the weight of their shared culpability without the merciful amnesia that had protected him.

Katarina wiped her eyes with the back of her hand, leaving streaks through the tears that had been flowing unchecked down her cheeks. "I tried," she admitted, her voice so quiet he had to strain to hear her. "I went to the same mind-healers you did, begged them to take away everything—the love, the magic, the memories, all of it. But the trauma bonding was too strong, the magical connection between us too deep. They said that removing my memories of our relationship would be like trying to extract my magical core itself, that it would either kill me or leave me a complete invalid. So I had to choose between death and remembrance, and I..." She gestured helplessly, a bitter smile twisting her lips. "I suppose I'm more of a coward than you are. I chose to live with the pain."

The ice murals on the windows were beginning to melt now, the magical cold dissipating as both their emotional states stabilized. Water ran down the glass in intricate patterns that seemed to form words in a dozen different languages—apologies and endearments and promises that dissolved even as they formed. The waitress had retreated entirely into the back room, leaving them alone with the settling silence and the weight of recovered memory.

"So what happens now?" Dmitri asked, though he wasn't sure he wanted to hear the answer. "You've given me back my memories, shown me what we were to each other, what we did together. But that doesn't change what happened to Baba Yelena. It doesn't bring her back or absolve us of responsibility for her death. And it doesn't erase the three years I spent learning to live without you, building a life that didn't include the possibility of that kind of connection." He could feel the familiar walls going up around his heart, the defensive mechanisms that had protected him during his recovery reasserting themselves despite everything that had been revealed.

Katarina stood slowly, smoothing down her skirt and reclaiming some of the composure she had lost during their emotional confrontation. "I don't know," she said honestly, and there was something almost relieving about her admission of uncertainty. "I came back to Moscow because the dreams were getting stronger, because I could feel you starting to remember whether you wanted to or not. I thought... I thought maybe if I could show you what we had been to each other, if I could make you understand that what happened was an accident and not some fundamental flaw in our magic or our love, then maybe we could find a way forward. But I didn't really have a plan beyond that." She laughed, but there was no humor in it. "I suppose I was hoping that love would be enough, that the connection between us would be strong enough to overcome the guilt and the grief and the three years of separation."

"And now?" Dmitri asked, rising from his own chair and facing her across the small distance that suddenly felt like an unbridgeable chasm. "Now that you've seen how I've changed, how I've learned to live without magic like ours, without the kind of risk and power and intensity we used to share—do you still think love is enough?" He could feel his magical core withdrawing, pulling back into the careful, controlled patterns he had spent years developing, patterns that prioritized safety over power, solitude over connection.

**Chapter 3**

Katarina studied his face for a long moment, her green eyes searching for something he wasn't sure he could give her. The silence stretched between them like a physical thing, filled with the weight of everything they had shared and lost and found again. When she finally spoke, her voice carried a resignation that cut him deeper than her earlier tears had.

"No," she said simply, and the single word seemed to echo in the empty café like a stone dropped into still water. "No, I don't think love is enough. Not anymore. Not when you've already made your choice to live safely, to practice magic that doesn't risk the kind of power we used to wield together. I can see it in the way you're holding yourself right now, Dima—you're already pulling away from me, already rebuilding the walls that the memory modification helped you construct. And maybe that's for the best. Maybe the mind-healers were right when they said that some connections are too dangerous to maintain, that some kinds of love are too destructive to survive in the real world."

She moved toward the café's front door, her steps measured and deliberate, but Dmitri could see the slight tremor in her hands that betrayed the effort this composure was costing her. Everything about her posture spoke of someone preparing for another goodbye, another long separation, another chapter of carrying grief and memory alone. The sight of it stirred something in him that was part protective instinct, part desperate longing, and part the recognition that walking away now would mean losing something irreplaceable a second time.

"Wait," he said, the word coming out more sharply than he had intended. "You can't just give me back three years of memories and then leave because I need time to process what that means. You can't drop the revelation that we killed my grandmother with magic we barely understood and then walk away when I don't immediately fall into your arms as if nothing has changed. That's not fair to either of us."

Katarina stopped with her hand on the door handle, her shoulders rigid with tension. When she turned back to face him, her expression held a mixture of hope and wariness that reminded him painfully of the way she used to look at him in the early days of their relationship, when they were still learning to trust each other with their deeper vulnerabilities.

"What are you saying?" she asked carefully, as if afraid that the wrong word might shatter whatever fragile possibility was forming between them. "That you want to try again? That you're willing to risk everything we've both built in the years since we were separated? Because I need you to understand, Dima—I can't go through losing you a second time. The first time nearly destroyed me, and I'm not sure I have the strength to survive it again if this doesn't work."

Dmitri found himself caught between competing impulses, part of him desperately wanting to close the distance between them and part of him equally desperate to flee before he could be hurt again. The recovered memories were still settling into place in his mind, creating a strange double vision where he could remember both versions of himself—the cautious librarian he had become and the passionate, reckless young man who had thought nothing of calling down storms to ease a city's suffering. Both versions felt equally real, equally valid, but they seemed to want completely different things.

"I don't know what I'm saying," he admitted, sinking back into his chair as the full weight of the situation crashed down on him. "Three hours ago I was a quiet, ordinary magical practitioner whose biggest concern was cataloging some fourteenth-century alchemical texts. Now I'm apparently someone who used to work magic powerful enough to reshape weather patterns and heal generational trauma, someone who had a passionate love affair that ended in tragedy and voluntary amnesia. I don't even know which version of myself is real anymore, let alone what I want or what I'm capable of."

The confession seemed to break something loose in Katarina, and she moved back toward the table with steps that had lost their earlier measured control. She sat down across from him again, close enough that he could smell the faint scent of rain and winter air that always seemed to cling to her skin, close enough that their knees bumped together under the small table.

"Both versions are real," she said gently, reaching across to touch his hand again. "The man you became after the memory modification is just as valid and legitimate as the one you were before. The healing process didn't erase who you are, it just... gave you space to develop in a different direction, to explore parts of yourself that had been overshadowed by our magical partnership. The question isn't which version is the 'real' Dmitri, it's which parts of both versions you want to keep as you figure out who you want to be going forward."

Her words made a certain amount of sense, but they didn't address the fundamental problem that was making his chest tight with anxiety. "How can I trust my own judgment about any of this? How can I make decisions about our relationship, about what kind of magic I want to practice, about what kind of risks I'm willing to take, when I can't even trust my own memories? For all I know, the feelings I'm having right now are just echoes of the magical bond we used to share, not genuine emotions based on who we actually are in the present moment."

Katarina was quiet for a long time, her thumb tracing small patterns on the back of his hand while she considered his question. The ice on the café windows had melted completely now, leaving only streaks of water that caught the afternoon light and threw strange shadows across the walls. In the distance, he could hear the normal sounds of Moscow life continuing—traffic and voices and the occasional rumble of the metro—all of it serving as a reminder that the world outside this small space was still proceeding along its usual patterns, unchanged by the revelation that had just turned his understanding of himself upside down.

"There's a way to find out," she said eventually, her voice thoughtful and hesitant. "It's not without risks, and it would require a level of magical cooperation that might be difficult given everything we've just discussed, but there is a technique that would allow us to examine our connection directly. Not the memories, not the emotions, but the actual magical bond itself. We could see whether what exists between us now is genuine or just residual energy from our past relationship."

Dmitri felt his pulse quicken at the suggestion, though whether from excitement or terror he couldn't say. The idea of deliberately working magic with Katarina again, of opening himself to the kind of power they had once wielded together, went against every instinct he had developed over the past three years. His training at the healing center had emphasized control, moderation, and above all, safety in magical practice. What she was suggesting sounded like exactly the kind of experimental, high-risk magic that had led to his grandmother's death in the first place.

"What kind of technique?" he asked, despite his reservations. "And what would be the consequences if something went wrong? Because I think I've had enough magical accidents for one lifetime." The question came out more bitter than he had intended, carrying the weight of all the fears that had shaped his careful, constrained approach to magical practice. He had spent years learning to channel his abilities in ways that posed minimal risk to himself and others, and the thought of abandoning that hard-won control was deeply unsettling.

"It's called the Revealing of Hearts," Katarina explained, her expression growing serious as she shifted into the clinical tone she had always used when discussing complex magical theory. "It's an old technique, pre-Christian probably, designed to show the true nature of the connection between two magical practitioners. We would each contribute energy to create a shared visionary space, and within that space we would be able to see our bond as it actually exists now, stripped of memory and expectation and wishful thinking. If what remains between us is just magical residue, we would see that clearly. If it's something genuine and present, we would see that too."

The explanation sounded reasonable enough in theory, but Dmitri's experience with magical theory had taught him to be suspicious of techniques that sounded too convenient or too perfectly suited to solving complex emotional problems. "And the risks?" he pressed. "Because there are always risks with magic that involves direct connection between practitioners, especially when those practitioners have a complicated history together."

Katarina's hesitation before answering told him more than her words did. "The main risk is that the technique requires us to lower all our magical defenses completely. For the duration of the working, we would be completely vulnerable to each other, magically and emotionally. If there's any unresolved anger or resentment between us, if either of us has any hidden agenda or unconscious desire for revenge, it could manifest in ways that could be... difficult to recover from." She paused, meeting his eyes with an intensity that made it clear she was not taking this suggestion lightly. "In the most extreme cases, practitioners have been known to suffer permanent magical damage or complete personality dissolution. It's not a technique to be undertaken casually."

"And yet you're suggesting we try it," Dmitri observed, leaning back in his chair as he tried to process the implications of what she was proposing. "You're suggesting that we trust each other enough to become completely magically vulnerable, despite the fact that our last major magical collaboration resulted in the death of someone we both loved. That seems..." He searched for the right word, finally settling on, "optimistic."

"Maybe it is optimistic," Katarina agreed, but her voice carried a note of something that might have been desperation. "But what's the alternative? We spend weeks or months trying to sort through recovered memories and confused emotions, never quite sure whether what we're feeling is real or just the echo of what we used to have? We try to rebuild a relationship on a foundation of uncertainty and mistrust? Or we walk away from each other again, this time knowing exactly what we're giving up?" She leaned forward, her green eyes bright with unshed tears. "I've spent three years living with the uncertainty, Dima. Three years wondering whether what we had was real or just a shared delusion brought on by magical resonance. I can't do it anymore. I need to know, one way or the other, whether there's something genuine still connecting us or whether it's time to let go permanently."

Dmitri found himself staring at her face, cataloging the small changes that three years had wrought. There were fine lines around her eyes that hadn't been there before, a wariness in her expression that spoke of hard-won experience, a controlled quality to her magic that suggested she had learned some of the same lessons about restraint and caution that he had. She was recognizably the same person he had loved, but she was also clearly someone who had been shaped by loss and separation just as he had been.

"If we did this," he said slowly, "if we actually attempted the Revealing of Hearts, where would we perform it? This technique sounds like it would require privacy and probably quite a lot of space for the magical energies involved. And I assume it's not something we could do in my communal apartment or your hotel room, wherever you're staying." He was stalling, he knew, asking practical questions to avoid making a decision about the larger issue, but part of him genuinely needed to understand the logistics before he could commit to something so potentially dangerous.

"I have access to a private space," Katarina said, and something in her tone suggested there was a story behind that access that she wasn't ready to share. "An old estate outside the city, abandoned since the Revolution but still magically active. The wards are strong enough to contain whatever energies we might raise, and it's isolated enough that we wouldn't risk involving innocent bystanders if something went wrong." She paused, then added with a slight smile, "It's also the place where we first met, actually. Where you taught me the Moscow style of fire magic and I showed you that water magic didn't have to be something to fear. If we're going to risk everything on one final magical working, it seems appropriate to do it there."

The mention of their first meeting stirred more recovered memories, images of a younger version of himself standing in the ruins of what had once been an elegant country house, teaching a red-haired stranger the fundamentals of flame conjuring while she laughed at his overly serious explanations and demonstrated water magic techniques that made his careful academic approach seem clumsy by comparison. He could remember the moment when their magic had first harmonized, the shock of recognition that had passed between them when they realized how perfectly their abilities complemented each other.

"When?" he asked, and the single word seemed to commit him to a course of action he wasn't sure he was ready for. "When would we do this? Because if I'm going to risk my sanity and magical integrity on a technique I've never attempted before, I'd prefer not to drag the decision out longer than necessary." The bravado in his voice was mostly false, covering a terror so profound it made his hands shake, but he could see from Katarina's expression that she wasn't fooled by his attempt at casualness.

"Tomorrow night," she said simply. "The moon will be dark, which will make it easier to focus on our own magical energies without external influences. And..." She hesitated, then continued with obvious reluctance, "And if we wait longer than that, I'm afraid I'll lose my nerve entirely. I've been building up the courage for this confrontation for months, and I don't think I can maintain it indefinitely."

Dmitri nodded, understanding more than she probably realized about the way courage could ebb and flow, about the importance of acting while the possibility of action still existed. "Tomorrow night, then," he agreed, and felt something shift in his chest at the words, some combination of excitement and terror that reminded him vividly of the way he used to feel before their most ambitious magical workings. "But I want your word that if either of us has any doubts during the actual ritual, if anything feels wrong or dangerous, we stop immediately. No matter how close we are to completion, no matter what we might learn by pushing forward. I won't be responsible for another magical accident."

"You have my word," Katarina said solemnly, extending her hand toward him in the formal gesture used to seal magical agreements. When Dmitri took her hand in his, he felt the familiar tingle of a binding spell settling into place around them both, ensuring that their promise to each other would hold even under magical compulsion or extreme emotional duress. It was a level of precaution that would have seemed excessive in his previous life, but which now felt like basic common sense given what they were proposing to attempt.

They sat in silence for several minutes after that, both of them seeming to realize that there wasn't much more to be said until after tomorrow night's ritual. The decision had been made, the terms agreed upon, and now all that remained was the waiting and the preparation and the hope that they would both still be recognizably themselves when it was over. Dmitri found himself studying Katarina's face again, trying to memorize the details in case this was the last time he would see her as she truly was rather than as filtered through magical revelation or disaster.

"I should go," Katarina said finally, releasing his hand and gathering her coat from the back of her chair. "I need to prepare the ritual space, and you probably need time to... process everything that's happened today. To decide how you feel about what we're planning to do." She paused at the edge of the table, looking down at him with an expression he couldn't quite read. "For what it's worth, Dima, I want you to know that whatever happens tomorrow night, whatever we discover about ourselves and each other, I don't regret coming back to Moscow. Even if this all ends badly, even if we're not able to find a way forward together, I'm glad I got to see you again. Glad I got to give you back the memories that were stolen from you."

"Katarina," he called as she reached the café door, and she turned back with obvious hope in her eyes. "I'm glad too," he said simply, and meant it despite everything else he was feeling.
